Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to deny credit for income attributable to runaway plants, where such income is included in the gross income of shareholders as income from sources within the United States. The taxable income of an electing corporation is reduced by the amount included in the gross income of a shareholder. Foreign shareholders or those not subject to tax are exempt from this provision. "For purposes of this subtitle, runaway plant income of an electing corporation not included in a shareholder's gross income is treated as taxable income from U.S. sources. Any gross income used to determine runaway plant income is excluded from qualification tests. Runaway plant income is the portion of taxable income of the electing corporation." The term 'disqualified facility' refers to a facility where operations start after March 3, 1993 for an electing corporation, unless the Secretary determines that it won't negatively impact employment levels in the US. The term 'disqualified facility' pertains to a facility starting operations after March 3, 1993 for an electing corporation. The corporation must file a request with the Secretary for a determination within 90 days of applying for tax incentives for the facility. The Secretary may consider a late request for facility incentives if there was reasonable cause for the delay. Revocation of a determination must occur within 3 years of facility operations starting. The Secretary may revoke a determination if there was a misrepresentation or failure to disclose material information by the electing corporation or a related person. Revocations are retroactive. The Secretary may revoke a determination if there was a misrepresentation or failure to disclose material information by the electing corporation or a related person. Revocations are retroactive. Any substantial increase in employment at a facility is treated as a separate facility for the electing corporation. Public comment is required for determinations under subparagraph (A)(i). The substantial increase in employment at a facility is considered a separate facility for the electing corporation. A substantial increase is defined as exceeding 110 percent of the average number of employees in the previous year's corresponding payroll period. The text discusses the requirements for a separate or supplemental application for tax incentives related to expansion. Special rules apply for distributions to meet qualification standards and determining related persons. The Secretary will publish notifications in the Federal Register regarding requests for determinations under paragraph (5)(A)(i) and the Secretary's determinations. The text of determinations and related background documents will be available for public inspection. The Secretary will publish determinations in the Federal Register for public inspection. Exemptions from disclosure rules apply, and the effective date is for taxable years ending after March 3, 1993. The time for filing a request under section 936(i)(5)(A)(ii) shall not expire before 90 days after the enactment of this Act.
